titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Peter Parker Collection
titlestmt.author: Finding aid by Todd A. Lane and Toby A. Appel

publicationstmt.publisher: Medical Historical Library, Harvey Cushing / John Hay Whitney Medical Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Thursday January 10, 2019 at 03:01

repository.corpname: Medical Historical Library, Harvey Cushing / John Hay Whitney Medical Library

did.abstract: Peter Parker graduated from Yale College in 1831 and from the Medical Institution of Yale College in 1834. Ordained as a Presbyterian minister in 1834, he sailed that year to China as the first Protestant medical missionary to that country. The papers relate to Parker's medical practice at the Canton Hospital and elsewhere, his missionary activities including his sermons, and his work for the U.S. Government as a diplomat to China. Most of the papers have been photographed at http://cushing.med.yale.edu/greenstone/collect/pppapers/ Use in conjunction with this finding aid.

langmaterial.language: Mostly in English. Some Chinese, Japanese, and French.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Manuscripts were donated by Peter Parker of Barrington, Illinois, May 16, 1960. Portraits and urinary calculi donated in the late nineteenth century by Peter Parker to the Medical School through Moses C. White, professor of pathology and a former missionary to China. These were later transferred by the Medical School to the Historical Library. Some materials, including photographs, were donated in 1966 by Mrs. William W. Cadbury, widow of an early twentieth century medical missionary to Canton.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright has not been transferred to Yale University.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Peter Parker Collection, Historical Library, Cushing/Whitney Medical Library, Yale University.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies
altformavail.p: Journals also available on microfilm. Most items have been digitized. Patrons may be requested to use these surrogates.

relatedmaterial.head: Associated Materials
relatedmaterial.p: The Library holds over 80 oil paintings by Lam Qua of Peter Parker's patients with large tumors. They were sent to the Medical School by Mrs. Harriet Parker in 1890 (see Correspondence under Herbert E. Smith, Box 1, Folder 20). They are represented in the Cushing/Whiney Medical Library Digital Library. See http://library.medicine.yale.edu/find/digital.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Peter Parker, medical missionary and diplomat to China, was born in Framingham, Massachusetts on June 18, 1804. His parents, Nathan and Catherine Parker, were farmers and devout followers of the orthodox Congregational faith. He attended Amherst College and then transferred to Yale College in 1830. After graduation in 1831, Parker studied both theology and medicine and was awarded an M.D. from Yale in 1834. In January 1834 he was ordained to the Presbyterian ministry in Philadelphia and, under the auspices of the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions, he departed a month later for Canton as the first Protestant medical missionary to China. With assistance from American and British benefactors, he opened the Ophthalmic Hospital at Canton in 1835. Parker specialized in treating diseases of the eyes, especially cataracts, but also performed general surgery including the removal of large tumors, and lithotomies. In 1847, he became the first physician to introduce anesthesia to China. With the onset of the Opium War (1840-1842), Parker returned to America in 1840, where he sought financial support for his hospital in the United States and Europe. In Washington, D.C., he met with government officials and urged the sending of an envoy to China. He met and married Harriet Colby Webster in 1841. In 1842, Parker resumed his medical missionary practice at Canton and became involved in diplomatic relations between America and China. In 1844 he served as translator and assistant under Caleb Cushing, U.S. Attorney General, and participated in negotiating the first treaty between the two countries, the Treaty of Wanghia. Dismissed by the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions in 1847 because the Board doubted the utility of medical missionaries, Parker continued his hospital until 1855 while acting as a part-time member of the American Legation. Due to a prolonged illness, Parker returned to the United States in 1855 only to sail back to China later that year as American Commissioner to China. Recalled by the U.S. government in 1857, Parker and his wife settled in Washington, D.C., where he was active in organizations such as the Evangelical Alliance for the United States of America and the Board of Regents of the Smithsonian Institution. His only child, Peter Parker, was born in 1859. The Rev. Peter Parker died on January 10, 1888.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection includes Parker's letters to his family beginning in 1825, instructions from the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions, many letters from Sir John Bowring, British consul at Canton and later governor of Hong Kong, and other correspondence relating to Parker's medical, missionary, diplomatic, and personal affairs. Writings include handwritten sermons and addresses. Medical reports and ledgers include Parker's handwritten quarterly reports of Canton Hospital, which contain lengthy case reports on a selection of surgeries. Two volumes of ledgers list patients treated at Canton Hospital with their diagnoses, and another ledger relates to Parker's private medical practice. Images include the buildings and staff of the Canton hospital and lantern slides of patients with large tumors, all dating from after Parker's time. The collection also includes miscellanea, memorabilia, and a box of preserved urinary calculi removed by Parker from patients in the hospital. Associated with the collection are over 80 oil portraits of Peter Parker's patients with noticeable tumors by Western-trained Chinese artist Lam Qua. Most of the Peter Parker Collection has been photographed. See http://cushing.med.yale.edu/greenstone/collect/pppapers/ Use in conjunction with this finding aid. The associated Lam Qua portraits of Peter Parker's patients are online at http://cushing.med.yale.edu/gsdl/collect/ppdcdot/

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into seven series: 1. Correspondence. 2. Journals. 3 Sermons, addresses, and other writings. 4. Medical reports and ledgers. 5. Miscellaneous. 6. Photographs, 7. Urinary calculi.

arrangement.p: Special correspondence followed by correspondence in alphabetical order.

did.unittitle: Parker, Peter to his family and related letters

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Peter Parker's father, Nathan Parker, died in 1826. Letters afterward are to his mother Catherine and his sister Catherine in Framingham, Massachusetts. Included in the folder are letters written to Parker's mother as Parker was sailing to China, and a letter about Parker that came into family hands.

did.unittitle: P. Perit to Mrs. Catherine Parker

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On Peter Parker's sailing for China on the Ship Morrison. Peter Parker had spent some weeks with Perit and his wife before the departure.

did.unittitle: James C. Richmond to Mrs. Catherine Parker

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letters to his mother and younger brothers, his sister Catherine, and his married sister Maria Fay.

scopecontent.p: Parker (or possibly someone later) cut a number of letters received from Bowring, sometimes leaving sizeable fragments including the signature, or sometimes only the signature. Dated fragments precede undated fragments and signatures.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: President John Tyler wrote a letter to the Emperor, sent with Caleb Cushing in 1844. A later U.S. president also wrote to the Emperor.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These materials were sent to Parker by Major Benjamin Perley Poore. Julius Heinrich Klaproth (1783-1835) was a German linguist, Orientalist, historian, and author. The materials include letters to Klaproth written in German and Chinese, and said to be about the Chinese language.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents

did.unittitle: C., W., Canton, to Dr. James Cooper, Junr., New Castle, Delaware

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Discusses a Dr. Parker's Chinese patient with a large butock, who is as yet afraid to undergo an operation. W.C. mentions enclosing a sketch which is not present. The description appears to correspond with the Lam Qua portrait of Wang Keking, Portrait No. 67. A transcript is included. This letter may have come to the Historical Library independently of materials donated by the Parker family.

[Smith, Herbert E.] Harriet Parker, Washington, D.C., to Herbert E. Smith [Yale University School of Medicine]

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Herbert E. Smith was Dean of the Medical School from 1885 to 1910. Mrs. Parker thanks him for the photographs and information on Peter Parker' collection of urinary calculi, and regrets that Parker is too ill to reply himself. Letter given to the Historical Library by Lottie G. Bishop, 1960.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Parker would be happy to receive a copy of Wood's recent book about China. Letter purchased from Henry Schuman, February 1945. The book may be William Maxwell Wood, Fankwei; or, The San Jacinto in the seas of India, China, and Japan (New York, 1859).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Peter Parker's handwritten journals including religious reflections and observations on events. The numbering of Journals 1-10 was created long ago and is retained. Journals 1-10 have been microfilmed and all journals have been digitized.

scopecontent.p: Peter Parker annotated on a separate slip, "The following Memoir was written during my Freshman year at A. [Amherst] Col."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes many handwritten sermons preached in Connecticut, on board the ship to China, in China, and in the U.S. and Europe (1840-1842) when promoting his missionary work. Addresses include those given by Peter Parker upon his departure to China and at the semicentennial of the Yale Theological Seminary. Papers include an essay written at Yale College, and an account of the wreck of the ship Larriston in 1853.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sermons were often repeated on later dates and/or in different locations. These dates and locations are noted by Parker at the top of the sermon. Sermons are listed here under the earliest location and date.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Labeled at a later date "P.P.s First Sermon." May be part of Wrentham, 1826.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Five loose pages inserted in the text.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Booklet of sermon material from which sermons were delivered also in New Haven, 1834 January 19; Plymouth, Conn., 1834 February 2; New Haven, 1834 February 9; North Haven, 1834, February 16; Cheshire, 1834 February 21; Yale College, 1834 March 1; Litchfield, 1834 March 8; Bristol, 1834 March 15; Center Church, New Haven, 1834 March 30; English Chapel, Malacca, 1835 May 31; and English Chapel, Singapore, 1835 July 12. Five inserted pages.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These reports contain case accounts of individual patients, in particular a number of patients painted by Lam Qua. See the typescripts in Box 7 which transcribe reports 1-11.

Reports of the Ophthalmic Hospital at Canton, 5-8

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Name of patient, age, birthplace, and occupation in Chinese, medical problems in English. One line per entry. Entries 40770-47129. Inserted is a drawing of a Chinese child with a growth on his face.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Continuation of above. Entries 47130-53049. Inserted as a loose sheet is a two-page document in Chinese on red paper.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In English. Parker's private medical practice including fees.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Parker's expenditures

did.unittitle: Bound volume of typescripts of the Canton Hospital Reports and of other publications on medical missionaries

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Bound volume (acc. 27408), donated by the widow of William Warder Cadbury, M.D. (1877-1959), who arrived in Canton 1909 where he taught at Canton Christian College and practiced at Canton Hospital. It contains typescripts of the Canton Hospital Reports, 1-11 (1835-1840); Extracts from William Lockhart, "Medical Missionary in China"; Medical Missionary Society Regulations and Resolutions, 1838; First Report of the Medical Missionary Society's Hospital at Macao; First Annual Report of the Medical Missionary Society, 1838; Inquest on a Dead Patient; Report of the Medical Missionary Society, 1839; Second report of the Medical Missionary Society of China, 1840; Report of the Medical Missionary Society, 1843.

did.unittitle: Bound volume of typescripts of primary printed sources related to medical missionaries in China and Peter Parker

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes an article by Parker. In the back of the volume are handwritten notes on urinary calculi. On spine: "Memorabilia Concerning Dr. Peter Parker." See urinary calculi, Box 11. Volume has bookplate of Samuel C. Harvey. This volume has not yet been photographed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes invitation from William Chesterman, the Master cutler-elect; menu; order of seating; and place card for Peter Parker.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Signed agreement to form a Congressional Temperance Society (1833) and words to "Ye Old Granite State," a temperance song.

did.unittitle: Letter from the Ambassador from France to Brazil, Washington, D.C., to Rothschild, Banker in London

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: In French. No clear relation to Parker.

did.unittitle: Printed hymn composed for a sermon by Peter Parker in Macao on the death of Mary Sword
Printed invitation to Mrs. H. Lindsly to attend a ball in honor of Lord and Lady Napier

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Mrs. Lindsly was Mrs. Parker's sister.

did.unittitle: List of paintings, statuary, and busts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These are likely the collection of the Smithsonian Institution. See General William T. Sherman to Peter Parker, February 13, 1873, Box 1, folder 20.

did.unittitle: New Year's greetings to Peter Parker from "a constant friend"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: On a laced sheet with tiny knitted gloves attached.

did.unittitle: Program of selections from Roberts' and Wright's Glee Choir

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: From England.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Five handwritten poems. One is "To Mrs. Parker on her Birth Day." Another, possibly written by Parker, is "A Mother's Farewell."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Three items by or related to Parker.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Very preliminary sketches of scenery with handwriting that is not Parker's.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Printed sheet: "Testimony to the truth of Christianity, given by Kiying late governor-general of Canton..." in English and Chinese; envelope on which is written "Canton Hospital/ Testimony to Christianity J.C. Stewart to P.P." See J. C. Stewart correspondence in Box 1, folder 20.

did.unittitle: Dr. J. C. Thomson, "Medical Missionary Society in China"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Printed columns pasted into a sewn pamphlet. The pamphlet recounts the history of the Society including Peter Parker's role.

did.unittitle: "Remarks of the Rev. Dr. B. Sunderland at the obsequies of Dr. Peter Parker," copy 1
"Remarks of the Rev. Dr. B. Sunderland at the obsequies of Dr. Peter Parker," copy 2
Notes between Carl Lohmann and Milton Winternitz about a Chinese manuscript

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Carl Lohmann was secretary of Yale University, and Milton Winternitz was the Dean of Yale School of Medicine. These two notes were found with the additional photographs from Canton Hospital and refer to gift materials from William Warder Cadbury related to Peter Parker or Canton Hospital. The manuscript was a druggist's request for payment of a bill.

did.unittitle: Peter Parker's Bible in Greek, 2 vols.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Latin titles are Vetus Testamentum and Novum Testamentum. Published in Glasgow. Peter Parker's China bookplate. This Bible has not been photographed.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes photographs of the oil paintings by Lam Qua, photographs of the staff of Canton Hospital after the time of Peter Parker, and lantern slides of Canton Hospital and of patients with large tumors.

did.unittitle: Photographs of Lam Qua paintings taken under the direction of Moses C. White

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Parker gave the portraits to Yale through Moses C. White, professor of pathology, who had been a missionary to China.

did.unittitle: Moses C. White's notes on paintings and loose photographs of paintings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The notes match cases to the Canton Hospital ledgers (Box 6, Folders 3 and 4), provide details of several of the cases, and give references to Parker's published reports.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Donated by the Mrs. William Warder Cadbury, 1966. Dr. Cadbury arrived in China in 1909, taught at the Canton Christian College, and practiced at the Canton Hospital. A number of snapshots are identified in Chinese. There are three loose photographs.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Donated by Mrs. William Warder Cadbury, 1966. Images are of the hospital, staff, and of Chinese patients with huge tumors of the type that Peter Parker treated. These slides have not been processed or photographed.

did.unittitle: Urinary calucli from Peter Parker's patients

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes the actual calculi, 31 photographs, and a drawing of the calculi probably created at Yale. Some of the photographs are matched to Canton Hospital case numbers. See Series 4, Box 7, folder 2 for notes and drawings of some of the calculi. The calculi have not been photographed.
